key_points: Congress confirmed the election results of President-elect Joseph R. Biden and Vice President-elect Kamala D. Harris.
The confirmation came hours after a violent incident where a pro-Trump mob stormed the Capitol.
A statement made highlighted that violence does not lead to victory, emphasizing that freedom wins and it is still the people's house.
One senator reconsidered their intention to object the certification of electoral votes due to the events at the Capitol, stating they could not in good conscience object.
The Senate rejected an objection to the electoral votes from Pennsylvania with a vote of 7 ayes to 92 nays.
The House of Representatives also rejected the objection to the electoral votes of Pennsylvania.
Joseph R. Biden Jr. received 306 electoral votes while Donald J. Trump received 232 electoral votes for the presidency.
Kamala D. Harris received 306 electoral votes while Michael R. Pence received 232 electoral votes for the vice presidency.
A total of 538 electors were appointed, with a majority of 270 required.
The certification of the electoral votes for President and Vice President will be entered into the journals of the Senate and the House of Representatives.
